name: Alain Ducasse
bio: Alain Ducasse is a French-born chef and restaurateur. He was born on September 13, 1956, in Orthez, France. Ducasse began his culinary career as an apprentice at the Pavillon Landais restaurant in Soustons. He has since opened a number of successful restaurants, including Restaurant Le Louis XV - Alain Ducasse in Monaco, which has three Michelin stars. Ducasse is also known for his signature dishes, such as the truffle-stuffed chicken and the sea urchin and lobster lasagne. In 2019, he was awarded the Lifetime Achievement Award by The World's 50 Best Restaurants.

recipes.name: Truffle Risotto
cookingMethod: In a large saucepan, heat the olive oil over medium heat.
Add the onion and garlic and cook until softened.
Add the rice and cook for a few minutes, stirring constantly.
Add the wine and cook until it has been absorbed.
Add the broth, a ladleful at a time, stirring constantly and waiting until each addition has been absorbed before adding more.
After about 18 minutes, the rice should be cooked but still slightly firm. Remove from heat and stir in the butter, Parmesan cheese, and truffle. Add salt and pepper to taste.

recipes.name: Roasted Lamb
cookingMethod: Season the lamb leg with salt and pepper.
Rub the garlic, rosemary, and thyme all over the lamb.
Place the lamb in a roasting pan and drizzle with olive oil.
Roast in the oven for about 1 hour and 15 minutes, or until the internal temperature reaches 145°F for medium rare.
Remove from oven and let rest for 10 minutes before carving.

recipes.name: Sea bass with fennel and lemon confit
ingredients: 4 fillets of sea bass, scaled and boned
cooking_method: Preheat oven to 350°F.
Place fennel and garlic in a baking dish, and add olive oil, salt and pepper. Mix well.
Lay the sea bass fillets on top of the fennel mixture, and add the lemon slices on top of each fillet.
Cover the dish with foil and bake for 20-25 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through.
Remove the foil and broil the fish for 3-4 minutes, or until the skin is crispy.
Serve hot.

recipes.name: Warm green lentil salad with smoked duck breast
ingredients: 1 cup green lentils, rinsed and drained
8 ounces smoked duck breast, sliced thinly
cooking_method: In a medium saucepan, bring water to a boil.
Add the lentils and simmer for 20-25 minutes, or until tender.
Drain the lentils and transfer to a large bowl.
In a small bowl, whisk together olive oil, vinegar, mustard, honey, salt and pepper.
Pour the dressing over the lentils and toss to coat.
Add the smoked duck breast, feta cheese and parsley, and toss gently.
Serve warm.

recipes.name: Beef tenderloin with truffle sauce
ingredients: Salt and freshly ground black pepper
4 ounces fresh black truffles, sliced thin
cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 400 degrees F.
Heat the olive oil in a large skillet over high heat until it shimmers.
Season the steaks generously with salt and pepper on both sides.
Add the steaks to the skillet and cook for 3-4 minutes per side until nicely browned.
Transfer the skillet to the oven and roast for 5-7 minutes for medium-rare.
Remove the skillet from the oven and transfer the steaks to a platter to rest.
Melt the butter in the skillet over medium heat.
Add the truffles and cook for 1-2 minutes until fragrant.
Add the beef broth and stir to scrape up any browned bits from the bottom of the pan.
Add the cream and cook for 2-3 minutes until the sauce has thickened.
Season the sauce with salt and pepper to taste.
Slice the steaks and serve with the truffle sauce.

recipes.name: Lemon tart
ingredients: 3/4 cup unsalted butter, cut into cubes
cooking_method: Make the Sweet Tart Crust according to the recipe below and press it into a 9-inch tart pan with a removable bottom.
Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F.
Zest the lemons and set aside.
Juice the lemons and strain the juice to remove any seeds or pulp.
In a large bowl, whisk together the sugar and eggs until pale and fluffy.
Whisk in the lemon juice and zest.
Place the bowl over a saucepan of simmering water (make sure the bottom of the bowl doesn't touch the water).
Whisk constantly for 8-10 minutes until the mixture thickens and coats the back of a spoon.
Remove the bowl from the heat and whisk in the butter, a few cubes at a time, until fully incorporated.
Pour the lemon mixture into the prepared tart shell.
Bake for 20-25 minutes until the filling is set and the crust is golden brown.
Let the tart cool completely before serving.

name: Joel Robuchon
bio: Joel Robuchon was a French chef who was known for his innovative and refined cuisine. He began his culinary training at the age of 15 and later earned a degree in pastry making. Robuchon went on to work in some of the most prestigious kitchens in France, including the Hotel Negresco in Nice and the Relais & Chateaux in Brittany. He also served as the personal chef to the Prince of Monaco for several years. Throughout his career, Robuchon was recognized with numerous awards, including 32 Michelin stars, more than any other chef in the world. He passed away in 2018, leaving behind a legacy as one of the greatest chefs of all time.

recipes.name: Pommes purée (creamy mashed potatoes)
ingredients: 2 pounds Yukon Gold potatoes, peeled and cut into 1-inch pieces
cooking_method: In a large pot, cover potatoes with cold salted water and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat and simmer until tender, about 20 minutes.
Drain potatoes and return them to the pot.
Add butter and heavy cream and mash until smooth.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.

recipes.name: Lobster with truffle broth
cooking_method: Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil.
Add lobsters and boil for 8-10 minutes, or until cooked through.
Remove lobsters from pot and let cool slightly.
Crack the shells and remove the meat.
In a medium saucepan, heat chicken stock and heavy cream over medium heat.
Add truffle oil and simmer for 5-7 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper to taste.
Divide lobster meat between four serving bowls.
Ladle the truffle broth over the lobster meat and sprinkle with chopped chives.
Serve hot.

recipes.name: Duck foie gras terrine with fig compote
cooking_method: Preheat oven to 325°F.
Remove the veins and sinews from the foie gras, and cut into small pieces.
In a large bowl, mix together the foie gras, Sauternes wine, brandy, salt, pepper, nutmeg, and allspice.
Pack the mixture into a terrine mold, and smooth the top.
Cover with foil, and place the mold in a baking dish.
Pour hot water into the dish to come halfway up the sides of the mold.
Bake for 50-60 minutes, or until a thermometer inserted into the center of the terrine reads 130°F.
Remove from the oven, and let cool to room temperature.
Refrigerate until chilled.
Serve with fig compote.

recipes.name: Leek and truffle tart
ingredients: 3 leeks, white and light green parts only, thinly sliced
cooking_method: Preheat oven to 375°F.
Roll out the pie crust and fit it into a 9-inch tart pan.
Prick the bottom of the crust with a fork, and bake for 10-15 minutes, or until lightly browned.
Remove from the oven and let cool.
Meanwhile, in a large skillet, heat the butter and olive oil over medium heat.
Add the leeks and cook, stirring occasionally, until tender, about 10 minutes.
Remove from heat and let cool.
In a large bowl, whisk together the eggs, heavy cream, Parmesan cheese, truffle oil, salt, and pepper.
Spread the leek mixture over the bottom of the cooled crust.
Pour the egg mixture over the leeks.
Bake for 30-35 minutes, or until the filling is set and golden brown.
Remove from the oven and let cool for 5 minutes before serving.

recipes.name: Caramelized apple tart
ingredients: 1/2 cup unsalted butter, at room temperature
3 large apples, peeled, cored, and thinly sliced
cooking_method: In a large bowl, cream the butter, sugar, and salt until light and fluffy.
Add the egg yolk and mix well.
Gradually add the flour, mixing until just combined.
Form the dough into a disk and wrap in plastic wrap.
Refrigerate for at least 1 hour.
Preheat the oven to 375°F.
Roll out the dough on a lightly floured surface to a thickness of 1/8 inch.
Fit the dough into a 9-inch tart pan with a removable bottom.
Prick the bottom with a fork and refrigerate for 15 minutes.
Line the crust with parchment paper and fill with pie weights or dried beans.
Bake for 15 minutes, then remove the weights and parchment and bake for an additional 10 minutes, or until lightly golden.
In a large skillet, melt the butter over medium heat.
Add the sliced apples and cook for 10-15 minutes, or until tender and golden brown.
Add the sugar, honey, cinnamon, nutmeg, salt, and vanilla extract, and cook for an additional 5-7 minutes, or until the mixture thickens and caramelizes.
Stir in the heavy cream and cook for an additional 2-3 minutes, or until the mixture is thick and glossy.
Pour the apple mixture into the prebaked tart crust and bake for an additional 10-15 minutes, or until the filling is set.
Let the tart cool to room temperature before serving.

name: Anne-Sophie Pic
bio: Anne-Sophie Pic is a French chef and the fourth female chef to hold three Michelin stars. She is the only woman to have held three Michelin stars twice. Pic is the granddaughter of chef André Pic, and daughter of Jacques Pic. She pursued studies in economics and management before deciding to follow in the family tradition of cooking. Pic began her training in the kitchen with her father, Jacques Pic, at his eponymous restaurant in Valence, France. After her father's death, she took over as head chef and successfully maintained the restaurant's three Michelin stars. In 2007, Pic opened her own restaurant, Maison Pic, in Valence, which has also been awarded three Michelin stars. She is known for her innovative, feminine take on traditional French cuisine.

recipes.name: Prawn and citrus salad with beetroot and raspberry
cooking_method: In a small bowl, whisk together orange juice, lemon juice, honey, mustard, olive oil, salt and pepper.
In a large bowl, toss together prawns, beets, raspberries and parsley.
Add the dressing and toss gently to coat.
Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Langoustine with bergamot, ginger and carrot
cooking_method: Preheat a grill or grill pan over high heat.
In a small bowl, whisk together bergamot juice, ginger, olive oil, salt and pepper.
Brush the langoustines and carrots with the marinade.
Grill the langoustines and carrots for 2-3 minutes per side, or until cooked through.
Transfer the langoustines and carrots to a plate and sprinkle with chives.
Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Suckling lamb with artichokes, lemon and rosemary
ingredients: 2 lbs suckling lamb, cut into 8 pieces
cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 375°F.
In a large ovenproof skillet, heat the olive oil over medium heat.
Add the lamb and cook until browned on all sides, about 10 minutes.
Add the garlic, rosemary, salt and pepper, and cook for 1-2 minutes.
Add the artichokes, lemon and chicken stock.
Cover the skillet and transfer to the oven.
Bake for 1 hour, or until the lamb is cooked through and tender.
Sprinkle with parsley and serve.

recipes.name: Millefeuille with Madagascar vanilla
ingredients: 1 vanilla bean, split lengthwise and seeds scraped
cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 400°F.
Unroll the pastry sheet onto a lightly floured surface and cut into 3 equal strips.
Place the strips on a baking sheet and prick them all over with a fork.
Bake for 10-12 minutes, or until golden brown.
Remove from the oven and let cool.
In a large mixing bowl, combine the heavy cream, vanilla seeds, and powdered sugar.
Whisk until stiff peaks form.
To assemble the millefeuille, place one pastry strip on a serving plate.
Spread a layer of whipped cream over the pastry and top with sliced strawberries.
Add another layer of pastry and repeat the process with the whipped cream and raspberries.
Top with the final pastry layer and spread a layer of whipped cream over the top.
Decorate with blueberries and mint leaves.
Serve chilled.

recipes.name: Blue lobster with green asparagus and verbena
cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 375°F.
Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil.
Add the lobsters and cook for 8 minutes.
Remove from the water and let cool.
Crack the shells and remove the meat, keeping the claws whole.
Set aside.
Blanch the asparagus in the boiling water for 2-3 minutes, or until tender.
Drain and toss with lemon juice.
In a medium saucepan, combine the white wine and shallots.
Cook over medium heat until the liquid is reduced by half.
Add the butter and cream, and stir until the sauce is thickened.
Stir in the chopped verbena and season with salt and pepper.
Arrange the asparagus on a serving plate and top with the lobster meat and claws.
Drizzle the sauce over the top and serve immediately.

name: Yannick Alleno
bio: Yannick Alleno is a renowned French chef who has won three Michelin stars throughout his career. He was born in Puteaux, France in 1968 and started his culinary training at a young age. Alleno has worked in some of the world's top restaurants, including Le Meurice in Paris and the Royal Mansour in Marrakech. He is known for his innovative approach to French cuisine, which combines classic techniques with modern flavors. Alleno has received numerous awards for his culinary achievements, including the Chevalier de la Legion d'Honneur and the Meilleur Ouvrier de France. In his free time, he enjoys traveling and exploring new ingredients and flavors.

recipes.name: Langoustine with passion fruit and sea urchin
cooking_method: Heat a skillet over high heat.
Add the langoustines and cook for 2-3 minutes on each side, or until cooked through.
Remove from the skillet and set aside.
Scoop out the flesh from the passion fruit and set aside.
Scoop out the roe from the sea urchins and set aside.
In a small bowl, whisk together lemon juice, olive oil, salt and pepper.
To serve, arrange the langoustines on a plate, spoon the passion fruit over the top, and sprinkle with the sea urchin roe.
Drizzle the dressing over the top and garnish with microgreens.

recipes.name: Beef with eggplant, ginger, and chili pepper
cooking_method: Heat the vegetable oil in a wok or large skillet over high heat.
Add the beef and stir-fry for 2-3 minutes, or until browned.
Remove from the skillet and set aside.
Add the eggplants to the skillet and stir-fry for 3-4 minutes, or until softened.
Add the garlic, ginger and chili pepper to the skillet and stir-fry for 1-2 minutes, or until fragrant.
Return the beef to the skillet and stir-fry for 1-2 minutes, or until heated through.
Stir in the soy sauce and oyster sauce.
Serve hot.

recipes.name: Milk-fed veal with Jerusalem artichoke and black truffle
cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 180C.
In a large frying pan, heat the olive oil over high heat.
Season the veal with salt and pepper and sear until golden brown on both sides.
Transfer the veal to a baking dish and bake in the oven for 10 minutes.
In the same pan, add the diced Jerusalem artichokes and cook until tender.
Add the veal stock and cook until reduced by half.
Add the butter and whisk until melted.
Slice the black truffle thinly.
To serve, place the veal on a plate, spoon the Jerusalem artichoke sauce over it and top with slices of black truffle.

recipes.name: Lemon tart with wild strawberries
cooking_method: To make the crust, mix the flour, butter and sugar in a food processor until the mixture resembles breadcrumbs.
Add the egg yolk and water and pulse until the dough comes together.
Shape the dough into a ball, wrap in clingfilm and chill in the fridge for 30 minutes.
Preheat the oven to 180C.
Roll out the dough and line a 20cm tart tin.
Prick the base with a fork and blind bake for 10 minutes.
Remove the baking beans and bake for another 5-10 minutes until the crust is golden brown.
To make the filling, whisk the eggs, sugar, lemon zest and juice in a heatproof bowl.
Add the butter and place the bowl over a pan of simmering water.
Whisk the mixture constantly until the butter has melted and the mixture has thickened.
Remove from the heat and strain the mixture into the tart crust.
Leave to cool completely.
Top the tart with the wild strawberries.

name: Guy Savoy
bio: Guy Savoy is a French chef born on July 24, 1953, in Nevers, France. He started his culinary journey by working as an apprentice under famous chef Troisgros brothers at the Restaurant Troisgros in Roanne. Later on, he opened his own restaurant, Restaurant Guy Savoy, which has been awarded three Michelin stars, and has become a popular destination for foodies around the world. Guy Savoy is known for his traditional French cuisine and his love for fresh, seasonal ingredients.

recipes.name: Artichoke and black truffle soup
cooking_method: In a large saucepan, sauté the artichokes, onion, and garlic over medium heat until soft.
Add the chicken stock and bring to a boil.
Reduce heat and simmer for 20 minutes, or until the artichokes are tender.
Using an immersion blender, blend the soup until smooth.
Stir in the heavy cream and black truffle paste, and season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve hot, garnished with chopped chives.

recipes.name: Crispy sea bass with Delice of Fennel
ingredients: 2 bulbs fennel, trimmed and thinly sliced
2 tablespoons fennel fronds, chopped, for garnish
cooking_method: Preheat oven to 400°F.
Season the sea bass fillets with salt and pepper.
In a large oven-safe skillet, heat the olive oil over medium-high heat.
Add the sea bass fillets, skin-side down, and cook until the skin is crispy and golden brown, about 5 minutes.
Transfer the skillet to the oven and bake for 8-10 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through.
Meanwhile, in a separate skillet, sauté the sliced fennel in butter until softened.
Add the white wine and chicken stock, and simmer until the liquid is reduced by half.
Stir in the lemon juice and season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the sea bass over the fennel mixture, and garnish with chopped fennel fronds.

recipes.name: Roasted quail stuffed with foie gras and truffles
cooking_method: Preheat oven to 400°F.
Season the sea bass fillets with salt and pepper.
In a large oven-safe skillet, heat the olive oil over medium-high heat.
Add the sea bass fillets, skin-side down, and cook until the skin is crispy and golden brown, about 5 minutes.
Transfer the skillet to the oven and bake for 8-10 minutes, or until the fish is cooked through.
Meanwhile, in a separate skillet, sauté the sliced fennel in butter until softened.
Add the white wine and chicken stock, and simmer until the liquid is reduced by half.
Stir in the lemon juice and season with salt and pepper to taste.
Serve the sea bass over the fennel mixture, and garnish with chopped fennel fronds.

recipes.name: Chocolate fondant with pear sorbet
cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/Gas 6.
Melt the chocolate and butter together in a bowl set over a pan of simmering water.
In a separate bowl, whisk the eggs, egg yolks and sugar together until pale and thick.
Fold in the melted chocolate and butter mixture.
Sift in the flour and cocoa powder and fold until combined.
Pour the mixture into 4 greased ramekins and bake for 8-10 minutes.
To make the sorbet, put the chopped pear, water, caster sugar and lemon juice in a small pan and bring to the boil.
Reduce the heat and simmer for 10 minutes until the pear is soft.
Blend the mixture until smooth, then pass through a sieve.
Churn the mixture in an ice cream machine according to manufacturer's instructions, then freeze until needed.
Serve the warm chocolate fondants with a scoop of the pear sorbet.

recipes.name: Warm brioche with caramelized butter and sea salt
cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 200C/400F/Gas 6.
Slice the brioche rolls in half and place on a baking tray.
Melt the butter in a pan over a medium heat and cook until it turns golden brown and smells nutty.
Remove the pan from the heat and stir in the caster sugar and sea salt.
Brush the mixture over the cut sides of the brioche rolls.
Bake in the oven for 5-7 minutes, until the brioche is golden and the butter has caramelized.
Serve warm.

name: Pierre Gagnaire
bio: Pierre Gagnaire is a renowned French chef and restaurateur known for his innovative and experimental cuisine. He was born on April 9, 1950, in Apinac, Loire, France. Gagnaire started his culinary career at the age of 14, working as an apprentice chef in various restaurants in Saint-Etienne. After completing his culinary training, Gagnaire worked in a number of Michelin-starred restaurants across France, including Maison Troisgros and Hotel Concorde Lafayette. In 1981, he opened his own restaurant in Saint-Etienne, which was awarded its first Michelin star just two years later. Today, Gagnaire is the head chef and owner of several Michelin-starred restaurants across the world.

recipes.name: Lobster with citrus fruits, coconut, and turmeric
cooking_method: Poach the lobsters in boiling salted water for 6 minutes.
Peel the citrus fruits, removing all the white pith. Cut the segments into small pieces.
Cut the coconut into small pieces.
In a saucepan, melt the butter and add the turmeric powder. Season with salt and pepper.
Remove the lobster meat from the shells and slice it. Reserve the shells for presentation.
In a mixing bowl, combine the lobster meat, citrus fruits, and coconut. Add the turmeric butter and mix well.
Place the mixture back into the lobster shells and serve warm.

recipes.name: Pigeon with artichokes and Parmesan foam
cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 200°C.
Clean and bone the pigeons, removing the skin and the wings.
Peel the artichokes and slice them thinly. In a saucepan, melt 50g of butter and sweat the garlic and thyme for 1 minute. Add the sliced artichokes and chicken stock, and cook until tender.
In a separate saucepan, melt the Parmesan cheese and heavy cream together. Blend the mixture with a hand blender until it becomes a smooth foam.
Season the pigeons with salt and pepper, and sear them in a hot pan with the remaining butter for 2 minutes on each side. Transfer the pigeons to the oven and roast for 6 minutes.
To serve, place the artichokes on a plate and top with the roasted pigeon. Finish with the Parmesan foam.

recipes.name: Beef tenderloin with beetroot, raspberries, and horseradish
cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 200°C.
Wrap the beetroots in foil and roast in the oven for 1 hour, or until tender. Once cooked, peel the beetroots and slice them thinly.
Season the pigeons with salt and pepper, and sear them in a hot pan with the remaining butter for 2 minutes on each side. Transfer the pigeons to the oven and roast for 6 minutes.
To serve, place the artichokes on a plate and top with the roasted pigeon. Finish with the Parmesan foam.

recipes.name: Sweet and sour pineapple with caramel and vanilla
ingredients: 1 fresh pineapple, peeled, cored, and sliced into bite-size pieces
cooking_method: In a large skillet over medium heat, combine the sugar and water.
Cook, stirring occasionally, until the sugar dissolves and turns a deep amber color, about 10 minutes.
Remove from heat and carefully stir in the pineapple pieces, vanilla bean, lime juice, lemon juice, honey, and salt.
Return the skillet to medium heat and cook until the pineapple is tender and the sauce has thickened, about 15-20 minutes.
Remove from heat and let cool slightly before serving.

recipes.name: Red mullet with fennel, tomato, and saffron
ingredients: 2 ripe tomatoes, peeled, seeded, and diced
cooking_method: In a large skillet over medium heat, heat the olive oil.
Add the fennel, onion, and garlic and cook until tender, about 5-7 minutes.
Add the tomatoes, wine, fish stock, and saffron, and simmer until the liquid is reduced by half, about 10 minutes.
Season the red mullet fillets with salt and pepper and place them on top of the vegetables in the skillet.
Cover and cook until the fish is opaque and cooked through, about 10-12 minutes.
Sprinkle with parsley and serve immediately.

name: Eric Ripert
bio: Eric Ripert is a French chef, author, and television personality. He is the chef and co-owner of Le Bernardin, a three-Michelin-starred seafood restaurant in New York City. Ripert began his culinary training at a young age and worked at several acclaimed restaurants in France before moving to the United States. He has authored several cookbooks and has been a judge on the television show Top Chef. Ripert is known for his innovative and refined approach to seafood cuisine.

recipes.name: Tuna sashimi with avocado and radish
cooking_method: Arrange the tuna slices on a platter.
Top with avocado and radish slices.
In a small bowl, whisk together soy sauce, sesame oil, honey, ginger, garlic, and scallions.
Drizzle the dressing over the tuna and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Lobster with curry and lemongrass
cooking_method: Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil.
Add the lobsters and cook for 8-10 minutes, or until the shells turn bright red.
Remove the lobsters from the pot and let them cool slightly.
Crack the shells and remove the meat, reserving the shells.
In a small bowl, whisk together curry powder, ginger, garlic, and coconut milk.
Heat the vegetable oil in a large skillet over medium heat.
Add the reserved lobster shells and cook for 2-3 minutes, or until lightly browned.
Remove the shells from the skillet and discard.
Add the curry mixture to the skillet and cook for 2-3 minutes, or until fragrant.
Add the lobster meat and cook for 2-3 minutes, or until heated through.
Season with salt and pepper.
Garnish with chopped cilantro and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Crispy duck confit with spiced quince and red wine sauce
cooking_method: Arrange the tuna slices on a platter.
Top with avocado and radish slices.
In a small bowl, whisk together soy sauce, sesame oil, honey, ginger, garlic, and scallions.
Drizzle the dressing over the tuna and serve immediately.

recipes.name: Chocolate tart with caramel and sea salt
ingredients: 1/2 cup unsalted butter, cold and cut into cubes
cooking_method: In a food processor, pulse together flour, cocoa powder, sugar, and salt until combined.
Add butter and pulse until mixture resembles coarse sand.
Add egg yolk and ice water and pulse until dough comes together.
Press dough into a 9-inch tart pan and chill for 30 minutes.
Preheat oven to 375°F.
Prick bottom of dough with a fork and bake for 15-20 minutes, or until firm.
Cool completely.
In a medium saucepan, combine sugar and water and cook over medium heat, swirling occasionally, until caramelized and amber in color.
Remove from heat and carefully add heavy cream, butter, and salt, stirring until smooth.
Pour caramel into cooled crust and chill for 10 minutes.
In a heatproof bowl, combine chocolate, heavy cream, and salt and set over a pot of simmering water.
Stir until chocolate is melted and mixture is smooth.
Pour chocolate mixture over caramel and smooth with a spatula.
Sprinkle with sea salt.
Chill for 30 minutes, or until set.
Slice and serve.

recipes.name: Coconut panna cotta with passion fruit
cooking_method: In a small saucepan, heat whole milk, heavy cream, coconut milk, and sugar over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until sugar has dissolved.
Remove from heat.
In a small bowl, sprinkle gelatin over 2 tbsp cold water and let stand for 5 minutes to bloom.
Whisk gelatin into milk mixture until dissolved.
Divide mixture among 4 small glasses or ramekins and chill until set, at least 2 hours
Pour caramel into cooled crust and chill for 10 minutes.
In a heatproof bowl, combine chocolate, heavy cream, and salt and set over a pot of simmering water.
Stir until chocolate is melted and mixture is smooth.
Pour chocolate mixture over caramel and smooth with a spatula.
Sprinkle with sea salt.
Chill for 30 minutes, or until set.
Slice and serve.

name: Hélène Darroze
bio: Hélène Darroze is a Michelin-starred chef from France. She was born into a family of restaurateurs and started her culinary career at a young age. After gaining experience in some of the world's top restaurants, including Alain Ducasse at The Dorchester and The Connaught in London, she opened her own restaurant in Paris. In 2008, she opened her first London restaurant, Hélène Darroze at The Connaught, which was awarded two Michelin stars in 2011. She has since opened a second London restaurant and a restaurant in Moscow. Darroze is known for her contemporary take on French cuisine and her focus on using seasonal and locally sourced ingredients.

recipes.name: Foie gras with Sauternes jelly and brioche
cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 375°F.
Remove the veins and any impurities from the foie gras, and season with salt and pepper.
Place the foie gras in a terrine dish, cover with foil, and bake in the oven for 25 minutes.
Remove from the oven and let cool for 30 minutes.
Meanwhile, in a small saucepan, combine the Sauternes wine and gelatin and let sit for 5 minutes.
Add the sugar, vinegar, and water and heat over medium heat until the sugar has dissolved.
Remove from the heat and let cool for 5 minutes.
Pour the Sauternes mixture over the foie gras, cover with foil, and refrigerate for at least 4 hours.
To serve, spread the butter on the toasted brioche slices and serve alongside the foie gras.

recipes.name: Monkfish with fennel, orange, and saffron
ingredients: 1 pound monkfish fillets, cut into 4 pieces
cooking_method: Season the monkfish fillets with salt and pepper.
In a large sauté pan, heat the olive oil over medium-high heat.
Add the monkfish and cook for 3-4 minutes per side, or until golden brown and cooked through.
Remove the monkfish from the pan and set aside.
In the same pan, add the fennel and sauté for 5 minutes, or until tender and golden brown.
Add the orange segments and saffron and cook for 1 minute.
Add the white wine and fish stock and bring to a boil.
Reduce the heat and simmer for 10-12 minutes, or until the liquid has reduced by half.
Add the cream and butter and stir until melted and well combined.
Return the monkfish to the pan and spoon the sauce over the top.
Serve immediately.

recipes.name: Warm chocolate cake with hazelnut ice cream
cooking_method: Preheat oven to 350°F.
In a large mixing bowl, combine flour, sugar, cocoa powder, baking soda, baking powder, and salt.
Add oil and eggs, mixing until just combined.
Add hot water and vanilla, mixing until smooth.
Pour mixture into a greased 9-inch cake pan.
Bake for 35-40 minutes, or until a toothpick inserted into the center comes out clean.
Let cool for 5-10 minutes before serving with hazelnut ice cream and fresh berries.

recipes.name: Lobster with leeks and shellfish cream
ingredients: 2 leeks, white parts only, finely sliced
Salt and freshly ground black pepper
cooking_method: Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil.
Add the lobsters and cook for 8-10 minutes, or until bright red.
Remove the lobsters from the pot and let cool slightly.
Using kitchen shears, cut the shells down the middle and remove the meat.
Heat the olive oil in a large skillet over medium heat.
Add the leeks and sauté until soft and translucent, about 5-7 minutes.
Add the wine and cook until reduced by half.
Add the cream and stock, and cook until the mixture thickens slightly.
Season with salt and pepper.
Divide the lobster meat among four plates, spoon the leek cream over the top, and sprinkle with chives.

recipes.name: Warm chocolate cake with hazelnut ice cream
ingredients: 1/2 cup unsalted butter, cut into pieces
cooking_method: Preheat the oven to 400°F.
Grease four 6-ounce ramekins with butter and dust with cocoa powder.
In a medium saucepan, melt the chocolate and butter over low heat, stirring occasionally.
Remove from the heat and let cool for 5 minutes.
In a medium bowl, whisk together the eggs, egg yolks, and sugar.
Whisk in the chocolate mixture.
Add the flour, vanilla extract, and salt and whisk until just combined.
Divide the batter evenly among the prepared ramekins.
Bake for 12-14 minutes, or until the cakes are set around the edges and soft in the center.
Let the cakes cool in the ramekins for 5 minutes.
Run a small knife around the edge of each ramekin and invert the cakes onto dessert plates.
Serve immediately with a scoop of hazelnut ice cream and a sprinkling of chopped hazelnuts.

recipes.name: Lobster with leeks and shellfish cream
ingredients: 2 leeks, white and light green parts only, sliced
cooking_method: Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil.
Add the lobsters and cook for 8-10 minutes, or until they are bright red and cooked through.
Remove the lobsters from the pot and let cool slightly.
Twist off the claws and crack them, then remove the meat and reserve.
Twist off the tails and remove the meat from the shells, then cut the meat into medallions and reserve.
Heat the butter in a large skillet over medium heat.
Add the leeks and cook for 5-7 minutes, or until they are tender.
Add the heavy cream, fish stock, and white wine.
Bring the mixture to a simmer and cook for 5-7 minutes, or until it has thickened slightly.
Stir in the chopped parsley and season with salt and pepper.
Add the lobster meat to the skillet and cook for 2-3 minutes, or until heated through.
